"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. The area adjacent to the bosque provides water to many in New Mexico. It should be maintained to protect endangered species, the river flow, and be more accessible to the public. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in New Mexico provides water to many people and should be maintained to protect endangered species, river flow, and be more accessible to the public. The Corps of Engineers aims to reestablish hydrologic connections to ensure healthy growth of native vegetation. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Critical restoration project: Immediate and substantial ecosystem restoration, preservation, recreation, and protection benefits.

Middle Rio Grande: Portion of the Rio Grande from Cochiti Dam to Elephant Butte Dam in New Mexico.

Secretary: Secretary of the Army.

SEC. 3. MIDDLE RIO GRANDE RESTORATION. The Secretary will implement critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting them based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing studies and plans. Local participation is required, with consultation and consideration of priorities from public and private entities involved in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed. The Secretary will implement critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, consulting with public and private entities involved in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed. Non-Federal interests will be required to cost-share 25% of the total project costs and provide land or rights-of-way. Under this Act, the Secretary will enter into agreements with non-Federal interests for critical restoration projects. Non-Federal interests must pay 25% of total project costs, provide necessary land and materials, cover all post-enactment operation costs, and hold the United States harmless from any claims. The critical restoration project under the Act includes maintenance, repair, replacement, and rehabilitation costs incurred after enactment. The project must hold the United States harmless from any claims, with recreational features not exceeding 30% of the total project cost. Non-Federal funding is required for the full cost of recreational features. The critical restoration project includes maintenance, repair, replacement, and rehabilitation costs. Recreational features should not exceed 30% of the total project cost, with non-Federal funding required for any excess costs. Non-Federal interests can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if work is done before the project cooperation agreement is executed. Non-Federal interests can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if work is done before the project cooperation agreement is executed. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
